event_description: OPEC set a target price of $18 per barrel, signaling a shift away from the market-share wars of 1986 toward coordinated price stabilization.
Marked the symbolic end of the Cold War, leading to the collapse of the Soviet Union and opening large Russian oil reserves to global markets.
Iraq’s invasion of Kuwait caused an immediate supply shock, doubling oil prices and triggering the Gulf War.
OPEC increased production quotas just as the Asian Financial Crisis reduced demand, creating a severe supply glut and collapsing prices.
The attacks on the United States initiated the War on Terror and permanently increased the geopolitical risk premium in oil markets.
A US-led invasion removed a major oil producer from the market for years and reshaped Middle Eastern supply dynamics.
Brent crude reached a record high amid the commodity supercycle driven by rapid demand growth from China and India.
The collapse triggered the Global Financial Crisis, causing a sudden collapse in oil demand and prices.
Widespread uprisings across the MENA region disrupted oil production, particularly in Libya, increasing supply uncertainty.
Advances in hydraulic fracturing enabled rapid growth in US oil production, challenging OPEC’s long-term market control.
OPEC, led by Saudi Arabia, refused to cut production despite oversupply, triggering a prolonged price collapse.
OPEC and non-OPEC producers agreed to coordinate output, creating a new supply management regime.
A collapse in global demand and storage capacity during COVID-19 caused extreme price dislocations, including negative WTI prices and sharp Brent declines.
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine triggered sanctions, supply re-routing, and a major global energy crisis.
Explosions damaged Nord Stream pipelines, permanently altering Europe’s energy relationship with Russia.
Brent prices continued a sharp decline from the July all-time high of $147 as high prices triggered global demand destruction.
Conflict threatened the BTC pipeline corridor; caused a temporary price spike and volatility before economic fears resumed dominance.
A surging US Dollar and deepening subprime crisis forced speculators to liquidate oil positions, driving Brent toward the $100 floor.
